occurrences.line_text: Thus as he spoke, loe with outragious cry
They reard a most outrageous dreadfull yelling cry,
Which suddeine horrour and confused cry,
And th'one of them with dreadfull yelling cry,
And as they went, they heard a ruefull cry
For ill it were to hearken to her cry;
Vnto his reskew, and with earnest cry,
But to her cry they list not lenden eare,
Where streight embraced, she to him did cry,
He rau'd, he wept, he stampt, he lowd did cry,
Thereat he shriekt aloud, that with his cry
Then gan she loudly cry, and weepe, and waile,
The cry whereof entring the hollow caue,
Then gan the Peoples cry and Commons sute,
Then gan she cry much louder then afore,
Tho looking vp vnto the cry to lest,
But chaste him still, for all his Ladies cry;
Gan cry aloud with horrible affright,
As if his cry did meane for helpe to call
Yet by the cry he follow'd, and pursewed fast.
And sure I weene, had not the Ladies cry
Gan cry to them aloud, to helpe ere all too late.
Die? out alas! then Calidore did cry:
The hue and cry was raysed all about;
Led with the infants cry, that loud did weepe,
And some of cats, that wrawling still did cry,
Then cryde the Dwarfe, lo yonder is the same,
To God for vengeance cryde continually,
That with the vncouth smart the Monster lowdly cryde.
He cryde, as raging seas are wont to rore,
Loe yonder he, cryde Archimage alowd,
And cryde, Mercie Sir knight, and mercie Lord,
Then loud he cryde, I am your humble thrall.
Which when the Palmer saw, he loudly cryde,
With that he cryde, Mercy, do me not dye,
Harrow now out, and well away, he cryde,
I burne, I burne, I burne, then loud he cryde,
These flames, these flames (he cryde) do me torment.
Cryde out, Deare countrey, Ã´ how dearely deare
Ay when to him she cryde, to her he turnd,
He fild with Hylas name; the Nymphes eke Hylas cryde.
Fy fy false knight (then false Duessa cryde)
They both arose, and at him loudly cryde,
Whom ouertaking, loude to him he cryde;
Cryde out, Ah mercie Sir, doe me not slay,
Behinde his Ladies backe, who to him cryde,
Which to her selfe lamenting loudly cryde,
With that aloude the faire Serena cryde
Then one of them aloud vnto him cryde,
Cryde out aloud for mercie him to saue;
Cryde mercie, to abate the extremitie of law.
Which when the Lady saw, she cryde amaine;
For which it loudly cald, and pittifully cryde.
Vntill Duessa loud to him gan crye;
But no man car'd to answere to his crye.
No other noyse, nor peoples troublous cryes,
Does throw out thrilling shriekes, & shrieking cryes,
Hart cannot thinke, what outrage, and what cryes,
That with their pitteous cryes, and yelling shrights,
Of cryes and clamors, which amongst them past,
Crying, O spare with guilty hands to teare
And crying Mercy lowd, his pitious hands gan reare.
Out crying, ï¿½ what euer heauenly powre,
Crying, Let be that Ladie debonaire,
Crying with pitteous voice, and count'nance wan;
Led with that wofull Ladies piteous crying,
In vaine loud crying, and into the flood
Crying to them their cruell hands to stay,
Crying to them in vaine, that nould his crying heare.
Crying to them in vaine, that nould his crying heare.
Crying for helpe aloud. But when as ny
Crying in vaine for helpe, when helpe was past.
Crying, and holding vp her wretched hands
Of one loud crying, which they streight way ghest,
Crying aloud to shew her sad misfare
Crying for food, did greatly him offend.
Crying in vaine to her, him to bemone;
Wringing her hands, and ruefully loud crying?
Of many haynous crymes, by her enured,
And th'actours won the meede meet for their crymes.
Of all those crymes she there indited was:
Faire Crysogone in slombry traunce whilere:
The rich Cteatus, and Eurytus long;
Whose depth exceeded not three cubits hight,
Whom she hath vow'd to dub a faire Cucquold.
Long thus he chawd the cud of inward griefe,
She chaw'd the cud of louers carefull plight;
Chawing the cud of griefe and inward paine,
Who well it wards, and quyteth cuff with cuff:
Who well it wards, and quyteth cuff with cuff:
Now cuffling close, now chacing to and fro,
More light then Culuer in the Faulcons fist.
A trembling Culuer, hauing spide on hight
As three great Culuerings for battrie bent,
But fierce Cundah gan shortly to enuie
Then he by cunning sleights in at the window crept.
His cunning hand gan to his wounds to lay,
As to descry the crafty cunning traine,
An Altare, caru'd with cunning imagery,
Then hopelesse hartlesse, gan the cunning thiefe
That cunning Architect of cancred guile,
With cunning traines him to entrap vnwares.
In cunning sleights and practick knauery.
As if it had by Natures cunning hand,
Her cunning web, and spred her subtile net,
Which cunning Craftesman hand hath ouerlayd
Aswell in curious instruments, as cunning layes.
From her most cunning hand escaped bee;
In which with cunning hand was pourtrahed
Framed in goldsmithes forge with cunning hand:
Yet goldsmithes cunning could not vnderstand
Like as a Smith that to his cunning feat
So well as could with cunning hand be wrought,
At that good knight so cunningly didst roue,
Which cunningly was without morter laid,
Were ruinous and old, but painted cunningly.
Can tune their timely voyces cunningly,
With boughes and arbours wouen cunningly,
Of that same wood it fram'd was cunningly,
One would haue thought, (so cunningly, the rude,
For that same net so cunningly was wound,
So cunningly enwouen were, that few
So cunningly she wrought her crafts assay,
And in her person cunningly did shade
Then tooke the angrie witch her golden cup,
Her golden cup she cast vnto the ground,
And in her right hand bore a cup of gold,
With cup thus charmd, him parting she deceiu'd;
In her left hand a Cup of gold she held,
Into her cup she scruzd, with daintie breach
The cup to ground did violently cast,
The guilty cup she fained to mistake,
Whom Ioue did loue, and chose his cup to beare,
And in her other hand a cup she hild,
Her golden cup to them for drinke she raught,
That I mote drinke the cup, whereof she dranke:
And eke emongst them litle Cupid playd
And Cupid still emongst them kindled lustfull fires.
Pleasure, the daughter of Cupid and Psyche late.
That Cupid selfe it seeing, close did smyle,
Yet cruell Cupid, not herewith content,
The maske of Cupid, and th'enchaunted
Cupid their eldest brother; he enioyes
On which when Cupid with his killing bow
For on a day, when Cupid kept his court,
Which when as Cupid heard, he wexed wroth,
All which when Cupid heard, he by and by
That had not yet felt Cupides wanton rage,
Like as Cupido on IdÃ¦an hill,
That she her dearest sonne Cupido sought,
Then of their armes: Mars is Cupidoes frend,
Full of great loue, but Cupids wanton snare
And eke all Cupids warres they did repeate,
To shew Dan Cupids powre and great effort:
And quenched is with Cupids greater flame:
For Cupids man with Venus mayd to hold,
And wondred much at Cupids iudg'ment wise,
And Nereus crownes with cups; his mates him pledg around.
And aye the cups their bancks did ouerflow,
And aye betweene the cups, she did prepare
Stayd not, till through his curat it did glyde,
His shield, his helmet, and his curats bare.
Gan coyne streight lawes to curb their liberty;
Did soone pluck downe, and curbd my libertie.
As much disdayning to the curbe to yield:
And Lordings curbe, that commons ouer-aw;
His stubborne steed with curbed canon bit,
Who can him cure, that will be cur'd of none?
his cure to hell does goe.
Aueugles sonne there in the leaches cure,
And well could cure the same; His name was Patience.
Old Glauce cast, to cure this Ladies griefe:
To cure her sonne, as he his faith had lent:
From your owne will, to cure your maladie.
Who can him cure, that will be cur'd of none?
Who ioyous of his cured conscience,
Ne can be cured of that cruell stroke
Of his old hurt, which was not throughly cured.
That doth with curelesse care consume the hart,
That now corrupt and curelesse they became.
In stead of Curiets and bases fit for fight.
In yuory sheath, ycaru'd with curious slights;
Her curious skill, the warbling notes to play,
With curious antickes, and full faire aumayld:
A worke of rich entayle, and curious mould,
Aswell in curious instruments, as cunning layes.
Most goodly it with curious imageree
But he to shift their curious request,
With curious Corbes and pendants grauen faire,
Nor sense of man so coy and curious nice,
An hart, not carried with too curious eyes,
A gorgeous girdle, curiously embost
To be vnarmd, and curld vncombed heares
And long curld locks, that downe his shoulders shagged,
Some frounce their curled haire in courtly guise,
Curled with thousand adders venemous,
His snowy front curled with golden heares,
With golden wyre to weaue her curled head;
As shepheards curre, that in darke euenings shade
Like as a curre doth felly bite and teare
But most that curre barking with bitter sownd,
Feeling some curre behinde his heeles to bite,
And a curre-dog; that doe him sharpe assay
The doubtfull current into diuers wayes:
Driues backe the current of his kindly course,
And as a Beare whom angry curres haue touzd,
Like dastard Curres, that hauing at a bay
As it had bene two shepheards curres, had scryde
But more enfierced through his currish play,
Ne from his currish will awhit reclame.
By all the meanes she might, to curry fauour
Curse on that Crosse (quoth then the Sarazin)
And cry, and curse, and raile, and rend her heare,
And all his seed the curse doth often cleaue,
All full of rage he gan to curse and sweare,
And curse his God, that did him so confound;
There gan he me to curse and ban, for lacke
About her cursed head, whose folds displaid
Her fruitfull cursed spawne of serpents small,
That such a cursed creature liues so long a space.
And cursed heauen, and spake reprochfull shame
A cruell witch her cursed will to wreake,
The cursed creatures doe eternally torment.
Some cursed vengeance on his sonne to cast:
His cursed hand gainst God, and on his altars daunst.
And said, Arise thou cursed Miscreaunt,
Till that their cruell cursed enemy,
That cursed wight, from whom I scapt whyleare,
That cursed man, low sitting on the ground,
Out of his hand she snatcht the cursed knife,
Arise, Sir knight arise, and leaue this cursed place.
On cursed tree, of that vnspotted lam,
Till from her cursed foe thou haue her freely quit.
Whylome, before that cursed Dragon got
Whiles cursed steele against that badge I bent,
Or cursed hand hath plaid this cruell part,
The cursed land where many wend amis,
Ah puissaunt Lords, what cursed euill Spright,
That same is Furor, cursed cruell wight,
That first did teach the cursed steele to bight
What dismall day hath lent this cursed light,
That cursed man, that cruell feend of hell,
Then gan a cursed hand the quiet wombe
That cursed weapon, when his cruell foes he queld.
One cursed creature, he by chaunce espide,
Most cursed of all creatures vnder skye,
Then gan the cursed wretch aloud to cry,
His cursed life out of her lodge haue rent:
And fowly said, By Mahoune, cursed thiefe,
Thy cursed hand so cruelly haue swayd
From yielding succour to that cursed Swaine,
One of Malegers cursed darts did take,
That either seemes some cursed witches deed,
Cursed the hand, that did so deadly smight
And cursed night, that reft from him so goodly scope.
His cursed hand withheld, and maistered his might.
Those cursed leaues, his charmes backe to reuerse;
Where she in darknes wastes her cursed daies & nights.
And those same cursed seedes doe also serue
Whilest both you here with many a cursed oth,
O cursed Eld the cankerworme of writs,
With cursed knife cutting the twist in twaine:
The crime, which cursed Ate kindled earst,
Whose cursed vsage and vngodly trade
Where this same cursed caytiue did appeare,
A cursed cruell Sarazin doth wonne,
Of which she vow'd with many a cursed threat,
Like as the cursed sonne of Theseus,
Gainst loiall Princes, all this cursed plot,
The cursed Ate, brought her face to face,
On which that cursed Idole farre proclamed,
Vnder that cursed Idols altar stone;
In sacrifize vnto that cursed feend:
The whiles the cursed felon high did reare
Her cursed head, although it itched naught;
In which her cursed tongue full sharpe and short
The cursed Serpent, though she hungrily
To sharpen him, and their owne cursed tongs did straine.
That cursed caytiue, my strong enemy,
Which follow'd her, with cursed hands vncleane
But none of all those curses ouertooke
With curses vaine in his auengefull ire:
And with vile curses, and reprochfull shame
And bitter curses, horrible to tell,
Cursing high Ioue, the which them thither sent.
Cursing his Gods, and himselfe damning deepe:
Cursing his hand that had that visage mard:
Oft cursing th'heauens, that so cruell were
And said, Caytiue, cursse on thy cruell hond,
He knocked fast, and often curst, and sware,
Exceeding mone, and curst that cruell chaunce,
Or curst the hand, which did that vengea[n]ce on him dight.
And curst, and band, and blasphemies forth threw,
Nights humid curtaine from the heauens withdrew,
With curtaxe vsed Diamond to smite,
But speare and curtaxe both vsd Priamond in field.
Her coleblacke curtein ouer brightest skye,
And curteise vse conceiu'd affection bace,
With silken curtens and gold couerlets,
And when her curteous deeds he did compare,
And comforted with curteous kind reliefe:
Thereat the curteous knight displeased was,
Ah curteous knight (quoth she) what secret wound
A sober sad, and comely curteous Dame;
Of kindnesse and of curteous aggrace;
To whom the Prince in curteous manner said;
Where they were entertaind with curteous
She caused them be led in curteous wize
For they all seemed curteous and gent,
Basciante did him selfe most curteous shew;
But mote I weet of you, right curteous knight,
Your curteous tongue, his prayses to compile,
Wise, warlike, personable, curteous, and kind.
Nathlesse she was so curteous and kind,
And shewd her selfe in all a gentle curteous Dame.
Yet could she not but curteous cou[n]tenance to her make.
Whereat they shewed curteous countenaunce.
With curteous words, in the most comely wize;
Where curteous Knights and Ladies most did won
Doth noble courage shew, with curteous manners met.
She Guyon deare besought of curtesie,
Of curtesie to me the cause a read,
But he his idle curtesie defide,
The which thy proffred curtesie denayd?
And euermore the Carle of curtesie accusd.
And her against sate comely Curtesie,
Can yeeld great thankes for such her curtesie,
But in the triall of true curtesie,
The goodly praise of Princely curtesie,
Both noble armes and gentle curtesie.
As Curtesie, to beare themselues aright
That should to me such curtesie afford,
That curtesie and manhood euer disagree.
Or curtesie with rudenesse to requite:
And all the complements of curtesie:
Both doing and receiuing curtesies,
For courting fooles, that curtesies would faine,
The great schoolmistresse of all curtesy:
Then they Malbecco prayd of curtesy,
But fast good will with gentle curtesyes,
Sir knight, mote I of you this curt'sie read,
That curt'sie with like kindnesse to repay;
And doe in stead thereof mild curt'sie showe
How each to entertaine with curt'sie well beseene,
And entertaining her with curt'sies meet,
Them fairely entertaynd with curt'sies meete,
The third had of their wardrobe custodie,
The custome of that place was such, that hee
Cast how to salue, that both the custome showne
As whylome was the custome ancient
According to the custome of their law.
Which doth obserue a custome lewd and ill,
To erect this wicked custome, which I heare,
And wicked customes of that Bridge refourmed.
And wicked customes make, those doe defame
For on a Bridge he custometh to fight,
His owne coate he would cut, and it distribute glad.
With which he cut a locke of all their heare,
Gan with new rage their shields to hew and cut;
It cut away vpon the yielding waue,
Were fixed at his backe, to cut his ayerie wayes.
Of this sad Realme, cut into sundry shaires
Too rathe cut off by practise criminall
Of the wide aire her way does cut amaine,
He wilfully did cut and shape anew;
When as he saw she should be cut in twaine,
And better to reforme, then to cut off the ill.
Is wont to cut off all, that doubt may breed,
There he the necke thereof did cut in twaine,
To beare so great a weight: he cutting way
With cursed knife cutting the twist in twaine:
Old Cybele, arayd with pompous pride,
Or Cybeles franticke rites haue made them mad;
As great a noyse, as when in Cymbrian plaine
Cymo, Eupompe, and Themiste iust;
The brother of Cymochles, both which arre
Atin Cymochles finds.
Vnto his brother, whom Cymochles men did call.
There Atin found Cymochles soiourning,
Cymochles; oh no, but Cymochles shade,
Cymochles; oh no, but Cymochles shade,
Fights with Cymochles, whiles his bro-
Whom bold Cymochles trauelling to find,
Which when farre off Cymochles heard, and saw,
Mongst which Cymochles of her questioned,
And now by this, Cymochles howre was spent,
Cymochles, that had neuer met before
Cymochles sword on Guyons shield yglaunst,
The whiles Cymochles with that wanton mayd
Then said Cymochles; Palmer, thou doest dote,
To whom Cymochles said; For what art thou,
At proud Cymochles, whiles his shield was wyde,
Cymochles twise, that twise him forst his foot reuoke.
Eft to Cymochles twise so many fold:
For when Cymochles saw the fowle reproch,
Cymodoce, and stout Autonoe,
Of luckelesse Marinell Cymodoce.
Amongst the rest, was faire Cymodoce,
His mother was the blacke-browd Cymoent,
Drew the smooth charet of sad Cymoent;
Lifht goote Cymothoe, and sweete Melite,
Doth euer wash, and Cynthia still doth steepe
And siluer Cynthia wexed pale and faint,
Now had faire Cynthia by euen tournes
His Cynthia, his heauens fairest light?
Ne let his fairest Cynthia refuse,
As when faire Cynthia, in darkesome night,
Of swift Eurotas, or on Cynthus greene,
After his chace on woodie Cynthus donne:
His ancient loue, and dearest Cyparisse,
Ease, on his robe in golden letters cyphered.
In which there written was with cyphers old,
May learned be by cyphers, or by Magicke might.
In cyphers strange, that few could rightly read,
The Aspine good for staues, the Cypresse funerall.
And aged limbs on Cypresse stadle stout,
And with sad Cypresse seemely it embraue,
There mournfull Cypresse grew in greatest store,
Or as the Cyprian goddesse, newly borne
Or that in Cyprus, both long since this same,
Ooraxes, feared for great Cyrus fate;
Goodly she gan faire Cytherea greet,
Whether in Paphos, or Cytheron hill,
That euen her owne Cytheron, though in it
Next great Gurgustus, then faire CÃ¦cily
Or that great house of Gods cï¿½lestiall,
Dame Cï¿½lia men did her call, as thought
High Cï¿½sar, great Pompey, and fierce Antonius.
And feeble nature cloth'd with fleshly tyre,
Some mouth'd like greedy Oystriges, some fast
Which flowing long and thick, her cloth'd arownd,
And whilest he bath'd, with her two crafty spyes,
And loath'd the loose demeanure of that wanton sort.
For light ylike is loth'd of them and thee,
She bath'd her brest, the boyling heat t'allay;
She bath'd with roses red, and violets blew,
And he himselfe himselfe loath'd so forlorne,
With him went Daunger, cloth'd in ragged weed,
And beath'd in fire for steele to be in sted.
And in conditions to be loath'd no lesse:
But Artegall was better breath'd beside,
But bath'd in bloud and sweat together ment;
That his bigge hart loth'd so vncomely vew.
He breath'd his sword, and rested him till day:
Bequeath'd to him, forslacked had so sore;
His daedale hand would faile, and greatly faint,
That her in daffadillies sleeping made,
Gathering sweet daffadillyes, to haue made
And on his dagger still his hand he held,
He to him raught a dagger sharpe and keene,
He would at her request prolong her nephews daies.
And end their daies with irrenowmed shame.
Therein haue I spent all my youthly daies,
Which spent their looser daies in lewd delights,
Where she in darknes wastes her cursed daies & nights.
Where making ioyous feast theire daies they spent
Now twenty daies, by which the sonnes of men
And wast his wretched daies in wofull plight;
Spending his daies in dolour and despaire,
For he whose daies in wilfull woe are worne,
To cloud my daies in dolefull misery,
That she mote match the fairest of her daies,
I wast my life, and doe my daies deuowre
But let me die and end my daies attone,
Within three daies (quoth hee) as I do here,
But when as daies faire shinie-beame, yclowded
That he mote fresher be against the next daies fight.
The last daies purpose of their vowed fight,
Yet being forst to abide the daies returning,
After that long daies toile and weary plight.
Downe to the house of dole, his daies there to deplore.
Ten daies (quoth he) he graunted hath of grace,
For if I liue till those ten daies haue end,
All which my daies I haue not lewdly spent,
Of former daies mishap, his sorrowes wicked sourse.
So forth he passed thorough that daies paine,
As any one, that liued in his daies,
Through woods and wastnesse wide him daily sought;
To many knights did daily worke disgrace;
Which by misdiet daily greater grew:
To leaue them to; but thorough daily care
To dare the thing, which daily yet I rew,
The righteous man, to make him daily fall?
And further from it daily wanderest:
That Titan rose to runne his daily race:
Which in her cot she daily practised.
And dying daily, daily yet reuiue:
And dying daily, daily yet reuiue:
He daily dyde, yet neuer throughly dyen couth.
Some daily seene, and knowen by their names,
And th'vlcer groweth daily more and more;
Daily they grow, and daily forth are sent
Daily they grow, and daily forth are sent
Daily he tempted her with this or that,
Or daily siege through dispuruayance long,
Calling men to their daily exercize,
By heaping stormes of trouble on them daily more?
In which I daily dying am too long.
And being once amisse growes daily wourse and wourse.
And th'earth it selfe how daily its increast,
